occurrences.line_text: Carelesse the man soone woxe, and his weake wit
Behold, Ã´ man, that toilesome paines doest take
Out of her fruitfull lap; how, no man knowes,
Yet no man for them taketh paines or care,
Yet no man to them can his carefull paines compare.
Why then dost thou, Ã´ man, that of them all
To ferry that old man ouer the perlous foord.
To shed your liues on ground? wo worth the man,
And soyld with durtie gore, that no man can
That am, I weene, most wretched man aliue,
Him when the old man saw, he wondred sore,
That cursed man, that cruell feend of hell,
What art thou man, (if man at all thou art)
What art thou man, (if man at all thou art)
A darkesome way, which no man could descry,
As eye of man did neuer see before;
And vgly shapes did nigh the man dismay,
And those with which th'EubÃ¦an young man wan
Like mightie pillours, this fraile life of man,
To serue to wicked man, to serue his wicked foe.
O why should heauenly God to man haue such regard?
Beside his head there sate a faire young man,
Foolish old man, said then the Pagan wroth,
That horse and man it made to reele aside;
But as a man, whom hellish feends haue frayd,
Thrise happy man, (said then the Briton knight)
Ne man nor beast may rest, or take repast,
And when it opened, no man might it close,
A carefull man, and full of comely guise:
A man of yeares yet fresh, as mote appere,
There sate a man of ripe and perfect age,
And therein sate an old old man, halfe blind,
This man of infinite remembrance was,
And that old man Eumnestes, by their propertis.
An happie man in his first dayes he was,
The wretched man gan then auise too late,
Then vp arose a man of matchlesse might,
The iustest man and trewest in his dayes,
First Gorboman a man of vertuous life;
Constantius, a man of mickle might,
A man, of many partes from beasts deriued,
That man so made, he called Elfe, to weet
Proofe be thou Prince, the prowest man aliue,
That it would tempt a man to touchen there:
The young man sleeping by her, seemd to bee
Said Guyon, See the mind of beastly man,
That man to hard conditions to bind,
Nor man it is, nor other liuing wight;
Vnder what coast of heauen the man did dwell,
How shall she know, how shall she find the man?
The man whom heauens haue ordaynd to bee
Behold the man, and tell me Britomart,
A mightie man at armes, and mickle fame
For neuer man he suffred by that same
Vnto the man, that of him tydings to her brings.
For her depart, that euer man did heare;
As euer man that bloudy field did fight;
Proud man himselfe then Braggadocchio deemed,
But thou good man, sith farre in sea we bee,
Thereat th'old man did nought but fondly grin,
Extremely mad the man I surely deeme,
The man by gentle meanes, to let vs in,
The good man selfe, which then the Porter playd,
They rudely droue to ground both man and horse,
Which th'old man seeing well, who too long thought
The wretched man hearing her call for ayd,
Was neuer wretched man in such a wofull cace.
And all the passions, that in man may light,
Said he, thou man of nought, what doest thou here,
The wretched man at his imperious speach,
What Ladie, man? (said Trompart) take good hart,
And pardon simple man, that rash did him displease.
The foolish man thereat woxe wondrous blith,
Soone as the old man saw Sir Paridell,
The old man could not fly, but fell to ground halfe ded.
The silly man that in the thicket lay
And loathsome life, of God and man abhord,
Forgot he was a man, and Gealosie is hight.
Far off aspyde a young man, the which fled
Yet thou vile man, vile Scudamore art sound,
O wondrous skill, and sweet wit of the man,
(Ah man beware, how thou those darts behold)
That no man forth might draw, ne no man remedye.
That no man forth might draw, ne no man remedye.
That man and beast with powre imperious
And to him said, Thou wicked man, whose meed
But he sad man, when he had long in drede
Amidst the bridale feast, whilest euery man
To be a man, such as indeed he seemed,
And wicked wordes that God and man offended:
Because to man so mercifull he was,
And was indeed a man of mickle might:
Vntrue to God, and vnto man vniust,
None but a God or godlike man can slake;
Nathlesse proud man himselfe the other deemed,
Each other horse and man to ground did send;
Glad man was he to see that ioyous sight,
A read thou Squire, that I the man may learne,
Come see the secret of the life of man,
That on an heape were tumbled horse and man.
That horse and man to ground he quite did beare,
A straunger knight, from whence no man could reed,
Ne certes wonder; for no powre of man
Fie on the man, that did it first inuent,
And ghesse the man to be dismayd with gealous dread.
That to the ground she smote both horse and man;
It was to weet a wilde and saluage man,
Yet was no man, but onely like in shape,
His neather lip was not like man nor beast,
A wofull wretched maid, of God and man forgot.
Arriuing there, he found this wretched man,
Whereas that wofull man in languor did abide.
Well weend, that he had beene some man of place,
Ah wofull man, what heauens hard disgrace,
And that which wont to vanquish God and man,
Whom after did a mightie man pursew,
That would haue maz'd a man his dreadfull face to vew.
This mightie man (quoth he) whom you haue slaine,
Ne was there man so strong, but he downe bore,
True he it said, what euer man it sayd,
Blessed the man that well can vse his blis:
I knockt, but no man aunswred me by name;
I cald, but no man answerd to my clame.
But I though meanest man of many moe,
Nor sense of man so coy and curious nice,
For Cupids man with Venus mayd to hold,
To which no wit of man may comen neare;
Swift Awniduff, which of the English man
I will them tell though vnto no man neare:
All loued vertue, no man was affrayd
An yron man, which did on her attend
He is (said he) a man of great defence;
That horse and man he equally dismaies,
And gan entreat that iron man below,
But not that arme, nor thou the man I reed,
Would ye remit it to some righteous man.
Did aske, what cause brought that man to decay,
But that same wretched man, ordaynd to die,
Sir Terpine, haplesse man, what make you here?
Much was the man confounded in his mind,
Ere long their Queene her selfe, halfe like a man
And euery while that mighty yron man,
Warn'd man and beast in quiet rest be shrowded,
And earely calling forth both man and beast,
Then why doest not, thou ill aduized man,
But he the man, that say or doe so dare,
The yron man, albe he wanted sence
Ah wellaway (sayd then the yron man,)
The loft was raysd againe, that no man could it spie.
A man of subtill wit and wicked minde,
On that vilde man, and all his family.
The iustest man aliue, and truest did appeare.
Like to a weake faint-hearted man he fared,
But when they of that yron man had told,
Vnto the man, whom thou doest loue so deare;
The sence of man, and all his minde possesse,
Each of whose lockes did match a man in might,
There is a mighty man, which wonnes here by
On man and beast, that commeth in her path.
A dreadfull depth, how deepe no man can tell;
Which when he saw, his yron man he sent,
And reasons brought, that no man could refute;
That euer scap'd: for of a man they say
That any man would nigh awhaped make.
To see the man, whose euerlasting praise
Backe to recule; vntill that yron man
Both man and beast doe fly, and succour doe inquyre.
Nathlesse the yron man did still pursew
That foot of man might sound the bottome plaine,
But he them ouerthrew both man and horse,
That whether man or monster one could scarse discerne.
And that same yron man which could reueale
That they the mildest man aliue would make
Now happy man (sayd then Sir Calidore)
Cald Maleffort, a man of mickle might,
No greater shame to man then inhumanitie.
But rudely rowld to ground both man and horse,
The wretched man, that all this while did dwell
A tall young man from thence not farre away,
To take me vp (as this young man did see)
So passed we, till this young man vs met,
So taking counsell of a wise man red,
For a man by nothing is so well bewrayd,
He was to weete a man of full ripe yeares,
Most pensiue man, through feare, what of his childe became.
Most ioyfull man her sire was her to see,
To be the man, that with such scornefull pryde
Calepine by a saluage man
A saluage man, which in those woods did wonne,
The saluage man, that neuer till this houre
With that the wyld man more enraged grew,
But after him the wyld man ran apace
And perill by this saluage man pretended;
But the wyld man, contrarie to her feare,
During which time, that wyld man did apply
Like this wyld man, being vndisciplynd,
That plainely may in this wyld man be red,
A saluage man matcht with a Ladie fayre,
Of this wyld man, whom they full busie found
Had not this wylde man in that wofull stead
That he had bene a man of mickle name,
But that wylde man, whom though he oft forbad,
The whiles the saluage man did take his steede,
With a wyld man soft footing by his syde,
Whilest she did weepe, of no man mercifide.
Of whom what was becomen, no man knew.
The whiles that mighty man did her demeane
That, were no might in man, nor heart in Knights,
Meane while the Saluage man, when he beheld
But Meliboee (so hight that good old man)
Doe them afflict, which no man can appease,
But the good man, nought tempted with the offer
Through hollow caues, that no man mote discouer
He sought the woods; but no man could see there;
Lucina came: a manchild forth I brought:
So long till all the entry was with bodies mand.
But in bad maner they did disagree:
Hast slaine my men in this vnmanly maner,
But he, that neuer good nor maners knew,
Vpon a mangy iade vnmeetely set,
Was ouerpast, and manhood well awake,
To measure manhood by the sword or maile.
Thereby thine armes seeme stro[n]g, but manhood fraile;
But trust vnto his strength and manhood meare,
This knight too late his manhood and his might,
By his sole manhood and atchieuement stout
Resolu'd him to assault with manhood stout,
In womans weedes, that is to manhood shame,
By th'authors manhood, nor the doers might,
And proue thy manhood on the billowes vayne.
And manhood rare, but terrible and stearne
That curtesie and manhood euer disagree.
Yet doest thou not with manhood, but with guile
Of loue full manie lessons did apply,
For she could d'on so manie shapes in sight,
Whereby great riches gathered manie a day,
All manie nights, and manie by in place,
All manie nights, and manie by in place,
That mongst the manie vertues, which we reed,
Manie a braue knight, and manie a daintie dame
Manie a braue knight, and manie a daintie dame
The raskall manie soone they ouerthrew,
Which had approued bene in vses manifold.
After long paines and labours manifold,
Else had his sinnes so great, and manifold
Her dearely doth imbrace, and kisseth manifold.
His heart did seeme to melt in pleasures manifold.
After his trauell long, and labours manifold.
For terrour of the tortures manifold,
Yet she her selfe is whiter manifold:
With pleasures manifold.
With which she sprinckled fauours manifold,
Approued oft in perils manifold,
She turn'd her loue to hatred manifold,
Her selfe, adorn'd with gems and iewels manifold.
The prayses of that Prince so manifold:
In which being consorted with Manild,
For him he loued aboue all mankind,
And all those ioyes that weake mankind entyse.
Of all the which, for want there of mankind,
And all mankinde do nourish with their waters clere.
Yet weend by secret signes of manlinesse,
And mighty hands forget their manlinesse;
And strooke at her with more then manly force,
That nigh his manly hart did melt away,
And greatly shunned manly exercise,
Eftsoones his manly forces gan to faile,
Whose manly hands imbrew'd in guiltie blood
Vpon his manly arme he soone addrest,
And this misseeming hew your manly looks doth marre?
When courage first does creepe in manly chest,
That all his manly powres it did disperse,
Ne let vaine words bewitch thy manly hart,
Her loued knight to moue his manly pace:
And bruze with clownish fistes his manly face:
He smote so manly on his shoulder plate,
In which that manly person late did fade,
And naked made each others manly spalles;
Else mote it needes downe to his manly brest
Not fit for speedy pace, or manly exercize.
Mixed with manly sternnesse did appeare
But all for praise, and proofe of manly might,
And manly terrour mixed therewithall,
His manly face, that did his foes agrize,
How like a Gyaunt in each manly part
And in his port appeared manly hardiment.
He little answer'd, but in manly heart
And made ech member quake, and manly hart to quayle.
And manly limbs endur'd with little care
But if through stout disdaine of manly mind,
Where is that dreadfull manly looke? where be
As to haue robde you of that manly hew?
And eke thy selfe, for want of manly hart,
His manly mynde was much emmoued therewithall.
Yet euermore it was his manner faire,
And in her modest manner thus bespake;
Yet was their manner then but bare and plaine:
All threatning death, all in straunge manner armd,
To whom the Prince in curteous manner said;
Who when his vncouth manner he did vew,
To read, what manner musicke that mote bee:
Which stately manner when as they did see,
Him seemed more their manner did agree;
In manner of a maske, enranged orderly.
The manner of their worke and wearie paine;
Whose office was, against all manner wights
Whose manner was all passengers to stay,
The manner of the Gods when they at banquet bee.
So forth he fared as his manner was,
This euill manner, which ye here maintaine,
What manner wight he was, and how yclad,
To chaunge the manner of his loftie looke;
He noursled vp in life and manners wilde,
Whose secret filth good manners biddeth not be told.
Whose life and manners straunge she neuer knew;
Which of all goodly manners is the ground,
And manners mylde were planted naturall;
As by his manners, in which plaine is showne
Doth noble courage shew, with curteous manners met.
That gentle bloud will gentle manners breed;
But the rude Porter that no manners had,
Such wondrous science in mans wit to raine
That tree through one mans fault hath doen vs all to dy.
Then is mans body both for powre and forme,
Till it reduced was to one mans gouernments.
As in that old mans booke they were in order told.
But when her sonne to mans estate did wex,
Made of a dead mans skull, that seem'd a ghastly sight.
So feeble is mans state, and life vnsound,
And makes ensample of mans wretched state,
That fierce young mans vnruly maistery;
Till that to ripenesse of mans state they grew:
Then since (quoth she) the terme of each mans life
They spide a little cottage, like some poore mans nest.
And time to steale, the threasure of mans day;
When as mans age was in his freshest prime,
Vntill the ripenesse of mans yeares he raught;
Or weigh the thought, that fro[m] mans mind doth flow.
Both darting forth faire beames to each mans eye,
T'obay the heasts of mans well ruling hand,
Or to misconstrue of a mans intent,
Exceeding much the measure of mans stature,
Since then in each mans self (said Calidore)
Vnto her happie mansion attaine:
To leaue that desert mansion, she cast
Resolu'd to build his balefull mansion,
To her fraile mansion of mortality.
Whiles sad Night ouer him her ma[n]tle black doth spred
And in a foule blacke pitchie mantle clad,
Who with her sable mantle gan to shade
And th'yuorie in golden mantle gownd:
Her mantle, colour'd like the starry skyes,
Her with a scarlot mantle couered,
Vnder thy mantle blacke there hidden lye,
And when thou spredst thy mantle forth on hie,
Vntill a Mantle she for him doe fynd,
He tooke it vp, and in his mantle wound;
Mantled with greene, and goodly beautifide
Mantled with greene, it selfe did spredden wyde,
Their watchet mantles frindgd with siluer round,
Ne is there hauke, which mantleth her on pearch,
The cruell markes of many' a bloudy fielde;
So many pathes, so many turnings seene,
So many pathes, so many turnings seene,
Yet was in knots and many boughtes vpwound,
Your first aduenture: many such I pray,
And in her many troubles did most pleasure take.
As many formes and shapes in seeming wise,
And many yeares throughout the world I straid,
That many erra[n]t knights hath brought to wretchednesse.
That causd her shed so many a bitter teare,
To many knights did daily worke disgrace;
For many yeares of sorrow can dispence:
She has forgot, how many a wofull stowre
High lifted vp were many loftie towres,
In many folds, and mortall sting implyes.
How many mischieues should ensue his heedlesse hast.
Full many mischiefes follow cruell VVrath;
All these, and many euils moe haunt ire,
And for his sake haue felt full many an heauie stowre.
Where earely waite him many a gazing eye,
There many Minstrales maken melody,
And many Bardes, that to the trembling chord
And many Chroniclers, that can record
Old loues, and warres for Ladies doen by many a Lord.
Where many skilfull leaches him abide,
Where many soules sit wailing woefully,
For many corses, like a great Lay-stall
To gather breath in many miseries.
As he had traueild many a sommers day,
Whose many heads out budding euer new,
His poynant speare, that many made to bleed,
For whose deare sake so many troubles her did tosse.
She wandred many a wood, and measurd many a vale.
She wandred many a wood, and measurd many a vale.
Had riuen many a brest with pikehead square;
Full many knights aduenturous and stout
(I witnesse am) in many a cruell fight;
The groning ghosts of many one dismaide
Which haue endured many a dreadfull stowre,
Ay me, how many perils doe enfold
Death and despeyre did many thereof sup,
Shot many a dart at me with fiers intent,
Mongst many, one that with his prowesse may
On which had many wretches hanged beene,
His garment nought but many ragged clouts,
Was lincked, and by him had many pledges dere.
For feare of many foes: but when they knockt,
With many rather for to go astray,
Many kind speeches they betwene them spend,
And goodly gan discourse of many a noble gest.
And many soules in dolours had fordonne:
Their heauenly notes, and make full many a louely lay.
And many bloudie battailes fought in place
The many fauours I with thee haue found,
Yet had he prou'd the powre of many a puissant knight.
So many furies and sharpe fits did haunt,
And after, all the raskall many ran,
Of many Dragonets, his fruitfull seed;
To proue how many acres he did spread of land.
That heapd on him so many wrathfull wreakes:
Like as it had bene many an Angels voice,
Many great Regions are discouered,
And threatned death with many a bloudie word;
Through many hard assayes, which did betide;
With percing shriekes, and many a dolefull lay;
And after, many bitter throbs did throw
That many errant knights hath foule fordonne:
The cursed land where many wend amis,
So shedding many teares, they closd the earth againe.
Which he by many rash aduentures wan,
Had wrought, and many whelmd in deadly paine,
And oft approu'd in many hard assay,
Seemes that through many yeares thy wits thee faile,
Vpon her eyelids many Graces sate,
Purfled vpon with many a folded plight,
Is farre renowmd through many bold emprize;
And many battailes fought, and many fraies
And many battailes fought, and many fraies
Whom sore he bett, and gor'd with many a wound,
And eke the Hag with many a bitter threat,
So me weake wretch, of many weakest one,
Full oft approu'd in many a cruell warre,
Full many doughtie knights he in his dayes
And shewd them naked, deckt with many ornaments.
That hath so many haughtie conquests wonne?
Through many a stroke, & many a streaming wound,
Through many a stroke, & many a streaming wound,
And purple robe gored with many a wound;
Doth not, I weene, so many euils meet.
By euery fornace many feends did bide,
Many great golden pillours did vpbeare
For which ye men do striue: few get, but many mis.
That many noble Greekes and Troians made to bleed.
In which full many soules do endlesse waile and weepe.
And looking downe, saw many damned wights,
Now to Pyrrochles many strokes he told;
Eft to Cymochles twise so many fold:
Besiegd of many foes, whom straunger
They wasted had much way, and measurd many miles.
And many good knights slaine, that haue vs sought to saue.
Yet was she woo'd of many a gentle knight,
And many a Lord of noble parentage,
Wherein were many tables faire dispred,
With many raunges reard along the wall;
About the Caudron many Cookes accoyld,
Courted of many a iolly Paramoure,
Close round about her tuckt with many a plight:
Might be compar'd to these by many parts:
Like many swarmes of Bees assembled round,
And things foregone through many ages held,
And many Giants left on groning flore;
For all so many weekes as the yeare has,
So many children he did multiply;
Now one, which earst were many, made through variaunce.
Which for this Realme found many goodly layes,
Her many deemd to haue beene of the Fayes,
Through great bloudshed, and many a sad assay,
A man, of many partes from beasts deriued,
And many bold repulse, and many hard
And many bold repulse, and many hard
And many arrowes vnder his right side,
And had not bene remoued many a day;
Where many Groomes and Squiers readie were,
At last farre off they many Islands spy,
For they haue oft drawne many a wandring wight
Where many Mermayds haunt, making false melodies.
In which full many had with haplesse doole
All these, and thousand thousands many more,
Of many beasts, that roard outrageously,
And shewd him many sights, that courage cold could reare.
Many faire Ladies, and lasciuious boyes,
Of many a Ladie, and many a Paramowre:
Of many a Ladie, and many a Paramowre:
Through many couert groues, and thickets close,
Full many Countries they did ouerronne,
And many hard aduentures did atchieue;
All had he lost much bloud through many a wound,
For whose deare sake full many a bitter stownd,
I haue endur'd, and tasted many a bloudy wound.
